item.title: western powers strike libya; arab league has doubts
item.description: western powers pressed ahead on sunday with a campaign of air attacks in libya, promising more strikes despite criticism by the arab league.

item.title: girardi and yankees' pick go back a long way
item.description: dante bichette jr., the yankees' no. 1 draft pick, has a long history with the man who may one day be his manager.

item.title: israeli rebuke of obama exposes divide on mideast
item.description: israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu bluntly told president barack obama on friday his vision of how to achieve middle east peace was unrealistic, exposing a deep divide that could doom any u.s. bid to revive peace talks.

item.title: israeli rebuke of obama exposes divide on mideast
item.description: israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu bluntly told president barack obama on friday his vision of how to achieve middle east peace was unrealistic, exposing a deep divide that could doom any u.s. bid to revive peace talks.

item.title: west strikes libya forces, nato sees 90-day campaign
item.description: western warplanes bombed muammar gaddafi's tanks and artillery in eastern libya on friday to try to break a battlefield stalemate and help rebels take the strategic town of ajdabiyah.

item.title: nato to run libya no-fly zone but not all action
item.description: nato countries agreed on thursday to enforce a no-fly zone in libya to protect civilians against muammar gaddafi's forces, but fell short of taking full command of all military operations in the north african state.

item.title: gaddafi tanks move in again on besieged libyan city
item.description: libyan leader muammar gaddafi's forces resumed their attack on the rebel-held town of misrata on wednesday, moving back onto the offensive just hours after western strikes silenced their guns.

item.description: the newest addition to "spider-man: turn off the dark" is a choreographer with an unusual background in video games.

item.title: gaddafi shells towns, rebels pinned down in east
item.description: muammar gaddafi's forces attacked two west libyan towns, killing dozens, while rebels were pinned down in the east and nato tried to resolve a dispute over who should lead the western air campaign.

item.title: mcdonald's profit is up; so are costs
item.description: the company is considering raising menu prices more, but that could scare off customers who dine there mainly because of the low cost.

item.title: 4 ways to keep down costs on debit, checking accounts
item.description: in the past year, banks have hiked monthly fees, imposed tougher minimum balance requirements and even taken away rewards programs.

item.title: presbyterian church to ordain gays as ministers
item.description: the presbyterian church voted on tuesday to allow the ordination of gays, becoming the fourth protestant denomination in the united states to make the move that experts say reflects a larger cultural shift.

item.title: n.b.a. roundup: spurs' skid without duncan reaches 3
item.description: philadelphia missed a chance to make up ground in the eastern conference as it lost to the sacramento kings in overtime.

item.description: libyan leader muammar gaddafi has likely been wounded in western airstrikes and has probably left tripoli, italian foreign minister franco frattini said friday.

item.title: pension funds to lead suit vs. goldman over abacus
item.description: a manhattan federal judge on friday named three pension funds as co-lead plaintiffs in an investor lawsuit against goldman sachs group inc to recover losses tied to the wall street's bank's alleged misleading statements about abacus, a product linked to subprime mortgages.

item.title: fed's fisher says pricey gasoline hurting growth
item.description: high gasoline prices are dampening u.s. economic growth, but the federal reserve has already done all it can to support the recovery, dallas federal reserve bank president richard fisher said on thursday.

item.title: japan stops radioactive water leak into ocean
item.description: the utility that owns japan's crippled nuclear reactor says that highly radioactive water has stopped leaking into the ocean.

item.title: peru election for president set for runoff
item.description: despite the recently surging candidacy of ollanta humala, a nationalist, preliminary projections on monday suggested that none of the candidates received the majority necessary to win.

item.title: coveting singapore's public housing system
item.description: singapore's public housing system is often touted as a model for other countries.

item.title: indonesia lashes citi over embezzlement, debtor death
item.description: indonesia on friday slapped lengthy bans on citibank's credit card and wealth management businesses over a case of alleged embezzlement and the death of a client following questioning by debt collectors.

item.title: israel rejects total pullback to 1967 borders
item.description: israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu headed for talks in washington on friday saying that u.s. president barack obama's vision of a palestinian state on the borders of 1967 could leave israel "indefensible."

item.title: planned wireless internet network threatens gps
item.description: nationwide broadband network to be built using airwaves next to those used for gps.

item.title: hamas says egypt limiting passage from gaza

item.title: ncaa rejects usc's appeal of football sanctions
item.description: the ncaa on thursday rejected southern california's appeal to reduce sanctions imposed on its storied football program, keeping in place some of the harshest penalties leveled against a school in a quarter-century.

item.title: libyan rebels flee as obama authorizes covert support
item.description: as libyan rebels fled in headlong retreat from the superior arms and tactics of muammar gaddafi's troops on wednesday, u.s. officials said president barack obama had signed a secret order authorizing covert support for the rebels.

item.title: senegal braces for "tahrir square" protest day

item.description: visas are expiring for haitians who came to the usa after the 2010 quake, and officials have not granted requests to let them stay and work. ...

item.description: his winless streak has reached 16 months, but tiger woods has not wavered as he works to fix his golf stroke.

item.description: mr. radonjic, who was one of six serbian nationalists convicted in a 1975 bombing in yugoslavia, later exerted influence over organized crime in new york.

item.description: although he was eliminated from "american idol's" season 10 competition thursday night, paul mcdonald is still smiling a day later. after performing bob seger's "old time rock 'n' roll" on wednesday's episode, the nashville-based rock singer received the fewest votes of the eight contestants and bid farewell with a cover of rod stewart's "maggie may."

item.title: china says detained artist ai weiwei's company evaded taxes
item.description: chinese police said a company controlled by artist ai weiwei had evaded a "huge amount" of taxes, xinhua news agency reported on friday, the first indication of the "economic crimes" behind his detention, which has triggered an international outcry. ai's sister, gao ge, said his family had not been officially notified of the tax accusations, which she said were another unfounded effort by the police to justify holding ai.
